Review | 60 West Bistro disappoints

Margarita flatbread, shrimp burger impress amid poor service, badly executed dishes

Review | 60 West Bistro disappoints

Nancy Miller, Special to The Courier-Journal 2:13 p.m. EST December 17, 2014

The Shrimp Burger at 60 West Bistro is pattied shrimp with chipolte slaw, sweet habenero aioli and served with house-made French fries. 12/8/14(Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)

Story Highlights

  • Rating: Two stars out four
  • Address: 3939 Shelbyville Road Telephone: (502) 719-9717
  • Cuisine: New American. Alcohol: Full bar. Vegetarian: Yes. Price range: Moderate.
  • Hours: Monday-Thursday, 4 p.m.-midnight; Friday and Saturday, 4 p.m.-2 a.m.
17 CONNECT 6 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Patience is a virtue that's not rewarded at 60 West Bistro & Martini Bar. On my first visit, I stood waiting in the middle of the bar/dining room for 10 minutes before anyone on the staff acknowledged my presence. Finally, a server asked, "May I help you?" I thought the help I needed was obvious, but asked whether I might be seated. Later, I wished he had said no, but he led me to a booth where I waited for my friend Leigh.

My second round of waiting began once I was seated. After a painfully long time of feeling invisible, the server came to the table. He was cordial and apologized for my wait, explaining that he had become sidetracked.

Leigh was running late so I amused myself with a half order of braised beef tacos ($11). There was plenty of beef and a fair amount of flavor that emerged from a considerable amount of chewing.

The Crab and Sweet Corn Fritters at 60 West Bistro are mixed with spices and served with roasted red pepper remoulade and sweet chili sauce. (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
The Margarita Flatbread at 60 West Bistro features fresh mozzarella, tomatoes, olive oil, and fresh basil with a balsamic vinegar drizzle. (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
60 West Bistro's Cajun Pasta is prepared with grilled Cajun spiced chicken, roasted red peppers, and penne pasta tossed in a spicy alfredo sauce. 12/8/14 (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)

Buy Photo Fullscreen
The Shrimp Burger at 60 West Bistro is pattied shrimp with chipolte slaw, sweet habenero aioli and served with house-made French fries. (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
The Braised Beef Tacos at 60 West Bistro contain a slow roasted, braised beef, creamy chipolte slaw, and are served with sour cream and cilantro salsa. (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen

    Last SlideNext Slide

    We split tomato and mozzarella salad ($6), mainly because I was curious about tomatoes at this time of year. They were red and meaty, not at all bad, but were overpowered by balsamic vinegar. It was the mozzarella that caused us both to say at the same time, "Are you kidding?" There was one dime-size piece of mozzarella.

    Four choices of skewers are offered in half- and full-size portions. My Asian steak skewer ($14/7) was quite good and the basil-tomato quinoa that accompanied it even better.

    The Cajun pasta ($16) was almost inedible. The sauce was ridiculously hot, to the point of totally obliterating any taste in the dish.

    Our evening was about noshing, which can be lots of fun. But not if plates with bits of uneaten food are left on the table from course to course.

    As we were heading out, a trip to the ladies' room was in order. It should also have been in order for someone from the staff. The room could have been tidier.

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    Review: Anoosh Bistro in Louisville, Kentucky is sublime

    On a return visit to 60 West Bistro & Martini Bar, Alex and I stood in the same spot where I had stood the night before hoping to be seated. Servers walked around us to get to the kitchen. After 10 minutes, we were asked, "May I help you?" Once again, our response that we hoped for a table turned out to be regrettable.

    Alex ordered a Manhattan and I a Diet Coke. The server returned in a few minutes, saying she had neglected to ask him what type of bourbon he preferred. He answered and she left, we thought to return with his drink. Back she came in another few minutes, not with the Manhattan, but with another question. "I forgot to ask if you want that up or on the rocks," she said. The third trip back produced the Manhattan. She was rather sweet. I can only assume she lacked training, which is easy enough to remedy. It's a remedy that is important since she works at a martini bar.

    RECIPE | Corbett's roasted duck with orange sauce

    Another server stopped by to bring me a second Diet Coke. "Why don't you grab that straw?" he helpfully suggested, meaning that I should reuse the straw in my original glass. He also deposited Alex's corn fritters ($10), which were a bit short on crab.

    Margarita flatbread ($10) had some of the mozzarella that should have been served with my tomatoes the night before. It was the best dish of my two visits. The shrimp burger was second runner-up with a nice amount of shrimp.

    When the same server brought the plates with my burger and Alex's flatbread, the small table was crowded with my glasses and the empty fritters plate. One option would have been for him to remove the unnecessary tableware. He chose to let me try to move everything around while he unsuccessfully attempted to place the new plates on the table. As my burger plate tipped, one of the fried Brussels sprouts ($6) toppled onto the floor. "Oops," he said. "Don't worry. It's not a whole one, just a skin." He picked it up and moved on. Alex and I laughed and moved out.

    I enjoyed 60 West Bistro and Martini a few years ago. Chef/owner Charlie Knieriem let it slip. But it doesn't have to be a fatal slip. He's a talented chef and smart restaurateur who can bring it back. I look forward to the comeback.

    You can email freelance restaurant critic Nancy Miller at millermadison@aol.com.Follow @WhatNancyThinks on Twitter.
